job_title: Prefer Not to Say to Keep the Review Anon in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Most fellow employees want to help you succeed. The campus is beautiful. Library and chapel are stunning.
cons: Reach out to people already here. Meet off-campus and ask if their office is a good place to work. Most are, some definitely are not.

pros: Beautiful campus and some additional benefits to the resources on campus.
cons: Toxic Management (senior management). Narcissistic behavior; speeches about caring for their employees and promoted an open door policy, yet they were inaccessible and would gaslight you if you went to them with any concerns. Experienced Gender & Class Discrimination. Although I was hired to promote DEIA, I still experienced, directly and indirectly, discrimination by senior management. I reported the incidents in my resignation letter and expressed concerns about promoting an institution that would allow such toxic behavior. They decided to fire me ahead of my end date, citing my inability to conduct my job due to my concerns. However, before my firing, I was taking on additional recruitment days, and they were going into a period when the interns were taking on the recruitment roles in preparation for the reading season. I was scheduled to leave during that time. They offered me a confidentiality agreement at my firing, which I did not sign. Inappropriate Behavior. The Director divulged sensitive information about why another employee (my direct supervisor) was let go without prompt. Work-Life Balance Unmanageable. The job itself asks for a lot for an entry-level position. Having had a 15-year career in a different field, I came to the position looking for a change and new challenges. As an Admissions Officer, you are exempt and don't receive any comp pay or days for the additional time you put in for working holidays, weekends, and nights outside your normal responsibilities. It seems management actively seeks inexperienced individuals to exploit their naivety in how a good workplace should be managed and how they should be treated. During the reading season, you could work up to 16 hours daily. During travel season, you are expected to travel on your personal time. It is highly discouraged to travel during work hours. God forbid you have any past experience and skills. They will take advantage of that and give you a larger workload than those at your same pay scale and title. Yet refuse to provide you with proper compensation. When I brought these concerns to management, the response I received was, "You gotta do what you gotta do." When I brought up not having the proper compensation or job title for the amount of work that I was involved in, the Director made a statement suggesting neither was he, making a comparison between the both of us. However, he was my supervisor with a higher title and better pay than myself, making it an unfair comparison. The Director would expect you to hop on calls after 5 pm and had no sense of boundaries between work and your personal time. I only have had this single experience in undergrad Admissions, but through networking, it seems this is commonplace in the field. I highly suggest normalizing unionizing in the industry for anyone looking to go into the undergrad Admissions field but would like to be treated respectfully. The student tour guides at Hamilton College have gone to these lengths to be treated fairly and have won.

review_title: Toxic culture needs to change or at least be looked at
pros: Great benefits and nice campus. Many people were very nice
cons:
Accounting . Thug Controller runs department adding nothing  but negativity while piling on work with zero path to success and no clear level of priorities. You can not have an opinion with her or she will be gunning for you. She will remind you how lucky you are to be there. 

Very toxic environment .. cursing, gossip, staff in fear of what she might do and say. This is 2022 and hostile environments are a thing of the past. 

Not sure how well Vassar HR is aware of this situation but they should interview the staff individually and as a group to assess. 

Most colleges will just sweep things under the rug and don’t know if Vassar is the same way.. that culture needs to change in THIS dept.

cons: the salary is horrible for staff..if you are a professor you make out quite well here but not if you are any kind of support staff. Their salaries start at lower than McDonalds or Starbucks for instance. They offer NO training when you take a administrative asst. job. You are on your own. There is definitely a hierarchal caste system here and we are on the bottom. Definitely a disrespect for women which is sad since this institution was initially built for the betterment of women.

review_title: Wish it paid enough to stay here
pros:
The people make it worthwhile. It is a strong community with supportive people, and although work life here is undeniably based on a class system and can be rigorously hierarchical, on the social side of things it is easy to connect with people across campus.
It's also a beautiful campus! The benefits are solid (though health insurance is prohibitively expensive if you are supporting another person).
Faculty housing for administrators is a crucial perk if you can get it - it's precarious, and they're tearing down buildings now, but it definitely helps with the cost of living.
The students are incredible and a delight to work with.
cons:
As mentioned before, can be prohibitively hierarchical.
No room for advancement - no real raises or promotion structure.
There is a great deal of distrust and sour institutional memory from events that have happened in the past - this can make collaborating difficult.
The cost of living here is high, and the pay isn't enough to live here, especially if you are own your own, doubly so if you are supporting somebody else.
The college doesn't seem to compare professions across other campuses -- there are professional norms in my profession that aren't acknowledged, managed, or compensated correctly here.

review_title: Work/study is necessary for many students
pros: Working amongst department faculty and staff often means you get offered special opportunities not proffered to the general student body.
cons: If you don't have a flexible position that allows you to choose your own schedule (outside your class schedule, of course), being a student on work/study sometimes means you must miss  important or popular campus events if they fall during your shift.

review_title: Vassar Is a Great Place to Work ... For a College
pros:
decent salary
excellent benefits, including for administrators tuition benefit for children and stepchildren (ie anyone you can claim as a dependent on your taxes) which means that if the student is admitted to Vassar they can attend tuition free but, if they attend another school Vassar will pay half of Vassar's tuition toward that school's tuition
good vacation benefit, including a week off between Christmas and New Years
beautiful campus
fantastic fitness center and free fitness classes of all kinds
cons:
everything moves very slowly in a college environment
many decision are made by committees, who endlessly hem and haw
the current economic downturns have made the college tighten its belt so that's impacting travel perks, raises

pros: I loved working with students and helping out in labs. It was a great way to supplement my educational experience at Vassar, and gain some work experience. The professors and students were all wonderful to work with. Students were highly motivated to succeed, and professors really wanted their students to do well. Overall great experience!
cons: The pay is pretty low ($8/hour and maximum of 10 hours/week), but it was perfectly acceptable as a part-time position while I was a student. For one of the classes I had to grade for, I also had significantly more than work than was possible in the allotted time, but you are not allowed to log overtime.

review_title: IT Division  of US is a good place to grow
pros: I enjoyed the camaraderie  of many of the Staff, Faculty and students.  There was a sense of achievement when projects were completed and that success was enjoyed throughout the team.
cons: At the time of my employment, the CIO was not one I admired. Many of the behaviors he portrayed were uncomfortable and I found some of his decisions to be less than appreciated by the staff.

pros: It was a great experience to be able to work alongside students and help them out during lab periods. It also gave me an opportunity to reaffirm some of my lab skills and make sure that I actually understood the underlying concepts. Furthermore, it was a pleasure to get to know the professors and work with them.
cons: Sometimes the labs took a long time and were not the most exciting things to supervise. I also was put in charge of a course that I wasn't completely familiar with.

review_title: Amazing work place with one major flaw
pros: Vassar's students are some of the brightest minds that I've ever come across. It's a pleasure to get to work in an environment that fosters such well-rounded future leaders.
cons: Given some of the campus climate issues, I know for a fact that students and faculty can sometimes feel like their grievances are not being heard. There needs to be more open dialogues about some of the biggest issues on campus.

review_title: Great place to work - intelligent and dedicated workforce, great campus life benefits.  Adequate pay and good benefits.
pros: You can feel that you are making a difference for the better on campus.  Beautiful surroundings in which to work.  Cooperative colleagues, even if departments are not fully cooperating..
cons: Some bullies in management positions - execs. not taking complaints about these managers seriously..  A certain amount of disconnect between departments - Bldgs & Grnds with CIS - hindering a comprehensive approach to projects.

pros: Benefits are fantastic- retirement, health care, 22 vacations days, very compassionate employer. The campus is beautiful and the people are friendly. With so many departments, there is a great deal of mobility up to a point.
cons: The mobility stops at a point and then there is no where else to go.  The salaries could be better, but the benefits really offset lower cash.  As an administrator, you get paid only once a month and that is very difficult to manage.

pros: There are flexible hours, you work at a great institution, your fellow employees are very interesting, if you like sports you'll love this job.
cons: Many jobs on campus allow for the student worker to do homework. This is not that kind of job. It is very hands on. You will sometimes have to work weekends.

job_title: Collection Management Assistant in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Payment is very decent, and we even got an exhaustive pay rise this year. Thanks to this decent amount of payment, I did not have to wait for my parents to help me financially, even though I only work in Vassar's library part-time.
cons: Sometimes we have to face the lack of materials that are necessary for working. I wonder why this should happen, given that Vassar College is quite affluent financially.

pros: Flexible Hours and small professor:student ratio. Very engaging and hands on experience and I learned to use a wide variety of equipment in chemistry synthesis and analysis.
cons: Research hours could tend to drag on sometimes. The Labs were not always well stocked and the equipment tended to breakdown more regularly than one would like.

cons: The con is that Vassar jobs place a cap on what you can make and it is difficult to find other ways to earn money on campus.
